imt: Arɨkʷajõ corn crop.seed get-\textsc{thv} \textsc{3cor-aux.mov-thv} cicada house=\textsc{abl}
src: arɨkʷajõ asisi aapi at-a se-ko-a kõtkõra tek=eri
trs: \textit{Arɨkʷajõ} got corn seed from \textit{Kõtkõrã}'s house.

The black-fronted piping guan bird\footnote{The black-fronted piping guan bird (\textit{Aburria jacutinga}) is a large bird that is easily identified, since in almost all its area of occurrence it is the only cracid with a white spot on the wing. Its scientific name comes from \textit{burria, aburri, aburria} = Colombian Amerindian onomatopoeic name for birds generally called \textit{jacu}; and from Old Tupi \textit{jacú} = Jacu, and \textit{tinga} = white, in reference to the head, nape and wings of this bird that has feathers with white coloration (\url{http://www.wikiaves.com.br/jacutinga}).} (that was around) defecated inside the house.
He (\textit{Arɨkʷajõ}) was there just lying in the hammock.

src: sete i-so-a a-jẽ=eri te kẽrã asisi ko
trs: (Then) he looked, (and thought): “Where does he (the bird) eat corn?”
Then (he said to this daughters): “I will follow him, my daughters.”

src: so-a kot kaap te pe=kaat so-a kot
trs: “I will look to see, I will look at that.”

src: pia se-to-a õẽp te kʷako se-set neara
trs: He (\textit{Arɨkʷajõ}) stayed there waiting for the black-fronted piping guan bird to come back.

src: atɨ sete s-itõp=na tõp=na se-ko-a pɨbot kõtkõra taap
trs: Poor guy, he followed him all the way until he arrived at \textit{Kõtkõrã}'s (Cicada's) village.’ (\textit{Arɨkʷajõ} followed the bird all the way to \textit{Kõtkõra}'s house)
He (\textit{Arɨkʷajõ}) entered the house, sat himself down, and was given food.
He sat down, then got up, and stayed around there.

src: ma te kẽra eke aose se-set-a-ra ke te Kõtkõra tak-iat
trs: “When is that man leaving?” said \textit{Kõtkõrã}'s daughters.

src: te-eri ka aose asisi 'at-a naat kop
trs: Through his mind, the man is carrying off the corn.’ (Lit. ‘It comes from him, the man is taking the corn.’)

src: tapsɨt=bõ i-'at-a asisi=bõ i-'at-a arakʷi=bõ i-'at-a komata=bõ i-'at-a kaat naat kop aose
trs: He got manioc, corn, peanuts, beans, he stayed there doing that (taking everything), the man (i.e., \textit{Arɨkʷajõ}).
Then, when he had already got it all, he left again.
He arrived again at his own hammock.
He just got there and asked his daughters:
“Where is your mother?”

imt: \textsc{1pl.excl}-mother \textsc{dem.dist}=\textsc{dat} move \textsc{foc} \textsc{dem.time} walking.palm seed get-\textsc{thv} \textsc{cop} \textsc{foc} \textsc{1pl.incl}-food=\textsc{vblz} walking.palm seed get-\textsc{thv}
src: ose-si jãõ=bõ ka te ikão taaga kit at-a naat te ki-iko=na taaga kit at-a
trs: “Our mother went over there at that time to get walking palm's seed for us to eat, get walking palm's seed,” (they replied).’{\footnotemark}

src: poret ejat-ot-a i-pek-a-ra taaga kit at-a-t-kʷa nop pegat
trs: “Then, go call her, it is no longer necessary to bring walking palm seed” (\textit{Arɨkʷajõ} told his daughters).
They heard him, the daughters, then they left, went straight there and arrived (where their mother was).

src: akʷa kɨp perek piora naat kop
trs: She was digging for wild \textit{cará} tubers.’{\footnotemark}
“Our father called you, mother.”

src: ki-ɨape ma ke te ki-opap=eri i-ta kaat ikão
trs: “(Call her) to make our \textit{chicha}{\footnotemark} from our corn here, that (is what he) said at that time.”
“To prepare manioc to make \textit{massaco},” that (is what he) said at that time.

src: erek tɨɨ=na s-itoabip e-toabip tõet ejat-taɨp-iat sara aose igot-e-rõp sete
trs: She said: “Poor bastard, I doubt he has a crop. You poor children, he is a man who has nothing.”’  (Lit. ‘She said: “Pitied one, I doubt his crop (exists). Poor people of your children, this man has nothing.”’)
They went again, his daughters.
“Mom said just that.” (And, thus, the daughters told their father what their mother had said.)

src: ke ebõ te se-taɨp-kʷa paat te
trs: “It is like that now (she is angry at me), but she'll calm down."
“She is still going to laugh,” he (said).’ (That is what \textit{Arɨkʷajõ} thought about his wife.)

src: pia se-to-a arẽp te aramira 'ip-a-t neara
trs: He stayed there waiting, then the woman came back again.
She was angry, poor \textit{Pãrarekosa}.

src: poget kop perop-ka pe=akʷa kɨp perek
trs: She stayed there, and then went to cook wild \textit{cará} tubers.
She ate, and stayed there the way she was (angry), until it got dark.
Then it dawned.’{\footnotemark}
(After that \textit{Arɨkʷajõ} came and said to his children:) ‘“I will cure your beverage.”
“You can drink! Drink!”
“I am going to make your teeth fall out.”
It happened really that way, their teeth fell out.
“It won't be hard, your food, my daughters.”’ (This sentence continues the speech of \textit{Arɨkʷajõ} to his children.)

src: kaat=na='ẽp poret ko-ap ko-ap=na te ki-jãj poget=i poret
trs: They stayed that way, our teeth, in order for us to eat.’  (Lit. ‘They became that way in order to be (our) eating instrument, our teeth stayed that way.')
They just drop out (and grow again).
(That's why) kids' teeth drop out.
It is always just that way.’ (‘The cycle keeps repeating itself, it is always like that.’)
That's how our teeth are.

src: kaap=ese naat aapi õ-sop te asisi
trs: That is how (they) found corn seed.
And that's how it appeared the things that we eat.
(But) that's how it was at those times.

src: kõtkõra-rop=na arop-õ te asisi naat eteet
trs: If it were not for \textit{Kõtkõra}, there would be nothing, no corn. (All edible things were first planted by \textit{Kõtkõra}, who was also a shaman).
(There would be) no corn.

src: arop-õ te piro tapsɨt akʷa kʷaako piro-ap
trs: There wouldn't be anything, no yucca, no \textit{cará} tuber, no sweet potato.
If it were up to \textit{Arɨkʷajõ}, he wouldn't own anything.
He possessed nothing.

src: kʷai mat i-ko kɨpkɨba 'a mat i-ko sete
trs: He only eats stone and fruit (as if he were not human).’ (Lit. ‘Stone is what he eats, and fruit is what he eats.’)
If it were not for this man (\textit{Kõtkõrã}), (there would be nothing.)
It's finished.
